snippet: If big cuts are made to federal programs that benefit the lives of the less fortunate, private donations are unlikely to help fill the gap left by government.
abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column contends that while New Yorkers give lavishly to charity, the bulk of their contributions do not make it to society's least fortunate members, because individuals are not skilled at giving efficiently; questions Republican assertion that charitable giving could make up for cuts to social service programs and taxes.
lead_paragraph: If big cuts are made to federal programs that benefit the lives of the less fortunate, private donations are unlikely to help fill the gap left by government.

headline.seo: Bulk of Charitable Giving Not Earmarked for Poor
